On Apr 25, 2007, at 1:03 AM, aimike002 wrote:

> This is the bit I'm still not clear on. In my example, things work OK
> up to & including adding innovation number 6 (link 3 to 5).
> But for the second genome when we try to add innovation number 7 (5 to
> 4) should we simply resuse innovation number 5 (5 to 4)?
> (even though when we draw out the resulting phenotypes the 5 to 4
> links are in two different places on the network).

Well.. in my implementation, when you split two nodes (a,b), you  
always get a specific location.  So, what you describe isn't the case.

Think of it as each node having a pair of coordinates on a 2D  
Cartesian grid.  If your network starts out with, for example, one  
input node, one bias node, and one output node, you might assign them  
initial positions of:

Node0: Input: 0,0
Node1: Bias: 0,1
Node2: Output: 1,0.5

I'm not going to attempt ASCII art b/c Yahoo groups botches  
everything.  But basically, this network is flowing from left to right.

Now, say you split 1 and 2.  You get a node between them; it's at  
(0.5,0.75) using our imaginary 2D system.

So, Node3 is always refers to a single specific node.  Hence NodeX  
does as well...  and so, Link (x,y) should also always be the same,  
and so yes, it should share the innovation number.

I'm sorry that I did not explain this very eloquently; but, I hope I  
got everything correct.

--Steve
--Apple-Mail-3--533605571
